doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/EM Money Trail Mild inflows in EM strong July subscriptions in ChinaEM Money Trail Mild inflows in EM strong July subscr_2025-08-29

passages.text: Mild inflows in EM, strong sub

EM equity funds squeezed in mild inflows (+\\$85mn) this week, following strong inflows last week (+\\$2.0bn). Within regional funds, GEMs posted marginal inflows (+\\$17mn), Asia ex- Japan saw a small sell- off (- \\$92mn, +\\$1.6bn last week), EMEA (+\\$101mn) continued its strong run for the third week while LatAm saw net inflows of +\\$60mn. Total inflows continue to be led by ETFs, which saw small inflows this week (+\\$367mn) while non- ETFs sold- off (- \\$281mn). EM ex- China saw small subscriptions (+\\$30mn). YTD EM equity fund flows are - \\$5.4bn (ETFs: +\\$39.2bn, non- ETFs: - \\$44.6bn).

Market- level flows. Among the few markets that posted inflows this week, Indonesia (+\\$246mn) posted a third week of subscriptions while Brazil (+\\$141mn) remained net- bought for the second week. Markets that report with a one- week lag were also positive: Turkiye (+\\$89mn) and Saudi (+\\$79mn). Qatar posted marginal inflows (+\\$13mn). In the outflows camp, redemptions accelerated in India (- \\$848mn, from - \\$58mn), extending the sell- off to seven weeks. Taiwan (- \\$829mn, - \\$2.9bn last week) and Korea (- \\$214mn, - \\$892mn last week) saw some moderation in outflows while South Africa (- \\$619mn, from - \\$369mn) and Thailand (- \\$400mn, from - \\$84mn) saw outflows worsen. Malaysia (- \\$178mn) and the Philippines (- \\$49mn) also sold- off. Among monthly reports from EPFR, China (+\\$4.3mn) and Hong Kong (+\\$3.8bn) saw sizeable inflows, while other markets were also in the green: Poland (+\\$298mn), Mexico (+\\$109mn).

F markets that do not publish official foreign transactions in their equity markets, we use monthly data from EPFR Global (they cover 12,000 international, EM and US funds with total net assets greater than US\$6.0trn).

During the month of July, funds were net buyers in China, Hong Kong, Australia, Singapore, Poland, Mexico, Chile, Peru, and Colombia and net sellers in China. Please see page 21 for consensus overweight and underweight markets.

We publish a Consensus Asset Allocation report every month, where we review the asset allocation of major emerging market fund managers relative to the MSCI EM index as at the end of the reporting month. We use two approaches. Our preferred approach is to count the number of managers that are meaningfully OW or UWa market, defined as greater than 2% deviation from the benchmark.The results are displayed in the tables. The other is a simple average of the managers' country allocation compared with the benchmark.Extreme positions of a few managers distort this analysis.
This report reviews the allocation of emerging market funds for 57 managers surveyed by EPFR Global as of end-June 2025.
**Consensus overweight markets:** Brazil, Mexico, Korea

**Consensus underweight markets:** China, South Africa, Taiwan,India, Malaysia, Thailand, Saudi Arabia, Philippines, TÃ¼rkiye, Czech,Egypt, Hungary, Peru, Poland, Chile, Greece, Colombia, UAE, Qatar,Kuwait.
Table 7: Survey of key EM managers' positioning relative to MSCI EM - for major EMs
Source: EPFR Global, MSCI, J.P. Morgan calculations
Table 8: Survey of key EM managers' positioning relative to MSCI EM - for EMs that are less than 2% of the benchmark

Source: EPFR Global, MSCI, J.P. Morgan calculations. Note: (1) <0.1% = zero weighting or bearish view. (2) The fund weightings are simple averages of global emerging market funds country weights tracked by EPFR. The survey covers 57 fund managers. (3) The calculation of OW is greater than 2% overweight versus the MSCI benchmark. UW is less than -2% of benchmark weighting (4) Fund weightings are as of 30 June 2025 and MSCI weightings as of 1 July 2025. Numbers in brackets are the previous month values. Potentially, Chinese stocks have been misclassified as Hong Kong, hence we show the combined weight for Hong Kong and China. Hong Kong investment may be providing non-China exposure.

J.P. Morgan uses the following rating system: Overweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will outperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); Neutral (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will perform in line with the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); and Underweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating and, if applicable, the price target, for this stock because of either a lack of a sufficient fundamental basis or for legal, regulatory or policy reasons. The previous rating and, if applicable, the price target, no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. In Americas equity research, some stocks under coverage have a rating but no price target; in these cases, we expect the stock will outperform/perform in line/underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe over the next six to 12 months. In our Asia (ex- Australia and ex- India) and U.K. small- and mid- cap Equity Research, each stock's expected total return is compared to the expected total return of a benchmark country market index, not to those Research Analysts' coverage universe. If it does not appear in the Important Disclosures section of this report, the certifying Research Analyst's coverage universe can be found on J.P. Morgan's Research website, https://www.jpmorganmarkets.com.
